Early Access Review
								Before anything else, let me explain the game. You own a kingdom. Why? Who knows. You build stuff (taverns, shops, barracks, etc.) in a large-ish grid of grass and trees. You attract people into your kingdom, in hopes of them buying some stuff from your shops, like your average tycoon, although as of yet it is a very small focus. The big focus is on quests. You send your heroes on certain types of quests (rescue, vanquish, deliver, etc.) in certain other kingdoms. You allot some points to certain categories, and they're on their way. Thats pretty much it. Build more, quest more. Thats kind of all it is now. Now on with the rating. First of all, if I could rate this game N/A, I would. This game is simply unstable. There are many many bugs and imbalances. The developer himself said the game cost almost nothing to make, so I truly think the game would have been shed in a far better light if he waited to release it on early access. Although it is on the right track, its hard to recommend it as it is. Here is a pros and cons list, with that out of the way:Cons:UnbalancedBuggySensory-depriving color pallette, nothing but green and brown and gold highlights the whole game.Somewhat repetative quests, with sliders that seem to do nothing (unlike the ever-important sliders in GDT) EDIT: Sliders are now gone, and are replaced with... nothing? Now its worse than before, but not stealing something anymore.Slow progression, esp. in building.Once money (sorry, 'gold') goes below 0, its game over. No exceptions or anything, just a game over screen.Heros slowly die, with no apparent way to heal them. You even get a healing potion store, but not for them I guess. EDIT: This is aparently now fixedKlunky UI(keep in mind that almost all of these cons are things that can very easily be fixed by tweaking some numbers and code, so its up to the developer to make things right, for me atleast.)Pros: Interesting and unique graphics (though they could still use quite a bit of work)Despite monotony, still quite fun. Things to research,Shops to run,Not much else to say. I recommend this game because it is absolutely on the right track. If everything goes as it is, this game will be good. I can't disrecommend this game because of unforseen bugs and unbalances. While the developer should have released it a bit later, he very well might not have gotten any playtesters, therefore not being able to find any of those bugs or unbalances. The core game is fun, and thats all I'm looking for. So overall, I'm cutting this game some slack. I'll probably only play it briefly after the large updates every few weeks or so. The developer very honestly says he will work as hard as he can to finish this game, but anything can happen to one lone developer. A caring, involved developer like this is what this game needs to be fixed. I just hope he will. As of now, the current update, wait to buy, but you eventually should.

 RPG Tycoon - Review Gameplay:This game features two different aspects (RPG and Tycoon, duh), which are brought together in a rather interesting, but initially confusing way. Basically half of the game happens in text boxes.You manage a kingdom, build it, take care of your people (your followers) and expand by meeting the needs of both your followers and your heroes.Heroes bring in the aspect of RPG: You use the heroes to gain gold, experience, supplies and reputation all around, by sending them on quests. These quests do have direct effects on your kingdom, but in terms of gameplay are basically a few textboxes and a progress bar. It basically brings in another aspect of management, next to the management of income, followers and overall expansion.The game was very confusing in the beginning, since you need to figure out how much you actually spend on working on your kingdom and how much you invest into your heroes and their quests. There is a big repertory on buildings and quests, so one is faced with a lot of decisions.The Tycoon part in general is filled with neat sprites, whilst the RPG part is pretty basic, yet it plays a big role in the development of your kingdom.The game also features quite a lot of bugs, which, for a full-release title, certainly is a big down.Pros:+The aspect of kingdom-management has been very well designed+Long lasting gameplay+Full workshop supportCons:-The RPG aspect of the game is textbased and very basic-BugsConclusion:The game seems to be in a strange harmony, with the graphic based kingdom management, and the text based quests, where you need to find the balance between these two aspects to be successful on your journey.Since this game is already full-release I can not ignore the bugs and they therefore also will be part of the final score:5/10 - in its current state.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

												It’s taken me nearly 18 months to finally getting around to playing RPG Tycoon, during which time it’s passed through Steam’s Early Access, had its full release and most recently released its first DLC entitled ‘Supply & Demand’.RPG Tycoon is a city builder at heart played from the perspective of a Ruler who resides over a Kingdom. For their Kingdom to prosper it’s the Ruler’s job to make his settlement appealing and attractive for heroes to visit. Heroes they can hire to then send out on quests to earn gold, happiness and fame for the Ruler’s Kingdom, so that in turn the Ruler can expand and improve their Kingdom.Simple, right?Well… no.The game starts as a simple concept, which soon spirals into a deep interconnection between buildings, heroes, gold and happiness. Want a hero? Build a house for them. Now the heroes want paid. Send them out on quests, etc. But then the heroes want paid more as they level up from XP gained from quests, and such is the fame of your heroes that other adventures now visit your little kingdom and they want food, drink and entertainment. So, you find yourself having to build a Tavern, which makes an income from the visitors. Now your heroes are tired and low on health from manner quests, so you need to build a Medical Tent.Somehow, you’ve managed to get through the first year comfortably. Your Kingdom is happy, your heroes are doing well, your Tavern has levelled up. However, your town is looking shabby and the visitors aren’t happy about the lack of decorations. They’re also not happy about other ‘things’ and for me this is where the only real issue I have with the game starts to show – there’s a distinct lack of visual feedback on what’s making visitors and your settlements unhappy.The lack of feedback makes it difficult to entirely understand how to improve your situation and stop your Kingdom going from being content and happy, to suddenly depressed. As far as I’ve experienced so far unhappiness is the only end-state in the game. Perhaps there’s a lack of money ending too, and perhaps your settlements get raided, but I’ve never actually made it that far. Three to four years in-game time is as far as I’ve managed before the sudden 0% happiness drop.A brief check of reviews and Steam Discussion group shows you there are bugs still in this game, which isn’t a crime by any means (even if some people have taken umbrage at DLC being released before old bugs have been fixed). The positive is that the game’s developer, Matt Gambell is very active on both Steam and Twitter to answer and reply to feedback on the game. So, in an environment where indie devs are often criticised by some for hitting early access too soon for a quick cash grab, it’s refreshing to be able to see an active developer who communicates with his player base and is keen to fix bugs.In fact, during the time I’ve taken to think and write about my experiences with RPG Tycoon, Matt Gambell has released an update that fixes an issue with Finance Happiness that was causing a drop in happiness rating. Yet, bugs remain, as shortly after starting a save game a few issues showed themselves including; rival kingdoms had reset & a complete game freeze.As you might expect from a title containing ‘RPG’ the game does have some basic RPG and tabletop elements to it. Heroes have attributes, which are used in quests (ranging from quick to epic) to gain fame and fortune. Yet the game lacks one essential element of any RPG or tabletop game and that’s a basic set of rules and glossary for the user to follow and understand. That’s not to see that the game doesn’t provide information, as it does in the form of hero screens and quest descriptions. It just lacks the explanation of what those attributes do, and how they’re used in quests. There’s no real bridge between the game design and the user’s experience. It’s mainly left to chance, prior understanding and just a little bit of luck.The little snippets of info and feedback that translate the developer’s thinking and reasoning behind the game’s mechanics into something the user can understanding (without giving the magic of the game away). At times I found the quest requirements unclear, and at times felt like I was guessing at what resources I should take on quests with me. Without a doubt I was guessing which slot they should go in to. On the plus side the game keeps a history of which combinations of items you’ve used on quests, so it does provide a small amount of feedback to the trial and error approach it pushes you into.I’m sure there’s a hope from the developer’s point of view that the text quest provides enough information for the user to know what to take. A similar approach is used when you’re offered a multiple choice situation during Epic Quests. There’s no real feedback or insight provided other than the quest text. So when it comes to choosing an option, you’re once again sort of just left guessing and hoping for the best. A roll check is then used to see if you meet the requirements, but the UI doesn’t actually tell which attribute was used in the roll check.So with all of that in mind I’m left feeling that RPG Tycoon perhaps left Steam’s Early Access a little too soon at the cost of detail and polish. The base of the game is there, it’s just missing the smaller details to make the game more user friendly. You can enjoy the game’s current state; it’s presentation and soothing music, certainly make it a relaxing game to play and of course with a bit of time invested you will start to understand how to play. It’s certainly a nice idea, and one I hope gets the polish it deserves to make it more user friendly, as as far as I can see that’s all it’s really lacking.A fun game, with an active developer that just needs that little bit extra to be fully enjoyable.

Long Story Short Version:RPG Tycoon is a very promising, solid, good game at its core; with several unique & original twists & variations of the RPG, Simulation, Town Building/Management Genres, that are all nicely & effectively tied together & implemented, to make up an overall, fun & enjoyable gaming experience that youd hope for & want & expect from a game like this, that can keep you glued to it for hours at a time.  The game has come a long way since its early days, with continued support, updates & content added at a reasonable pace, with yet more work to be done & bugs that may or may not pop up along the way, but also with a diligent & friendly Dev that has stuck with it since the beginning & continues to update, modify & bug smash along the way & is routinely responsive & listens to his community.  *End LSSV/lazy/ADD TLDR version.*In-Depth analysis of the game & the Developers performance to date:The foundation the Dev has laid down for this game has always been solid & the RPG, Simulation, Town-Building/Management aspects incorporated into this game has always had lots of potential from its early days & is mostly why Ive kept a good eye on it since then.  It looked promising enough back then but I was on the fence for several months, hesitant, mostly due to the critical reviews, while still checking back on it periodically.  Eventually though, enough time went by & after keeping an active interest & a keen eye on it, & seeing continued progress, development & improvements & watching his YouTube vids, I felt like this was a guy that was truly into his work & committed to seeing it through.  So I finally decided to give in & I bought the game..played it & have had many hours of fun with it since then.Since then & along the way, many things have continued to be added, updated, improved upon & expanded; some things becoming bugged, some things unbugged; all at a consistently reasonable rate; all of which is the standard norm for Early Access games with a small team.  Its just himself & I think maybe he collaborates with 1 or 2 others.  Rinse, repeat; its an ongoing process, but one which the Dev has continued to see through on an acceptable basis.  Aside from his normal To-Do list & agenda of updating & progressing the game over time in his own visions, hes also been receptive to the posts people have made with bugs/suggestions, etc; as evidenced by the past posts from myself & others here & the change-logs & resulting game-play changes that followed.At one point, due to having a vested interest in this game; since its something very different & so nicely encompasses so many cool & different traits from other games & genres that I really like & since Ive always really hoped to see this game in completion someday; in my haste, I hadnt seen any Account activity or Discussion Forum posts from the Dev in about a month & a half, so was worried that the Dev might have gone bye-bye as too many of them far too often do, with EA games these days...but he promptly & politely responded, simply pointing out he always keeps a watchful eye, just not always from the Dev Account, which actually makes sense in hindsight.  On that note, occasionally there will be the random/rare person that posts bugs/suggestions or w/e & then a week or 2 or more goes by without a response from the Dev & that person becomes upset or says stuff like, "Oh the Dev must not care". etc;  Which to be fair to them, up to a point, thats understandable.  I even jumped the gun myself once.  Its not unusual...& in fact is sadly half expected anymore with EA games, for the Dev to bail on a game, or just not be at all involved with the community.  But I can personally & honestly state, thats just not the case here, to this date.  He is just one guy & has his own personal RL stuff going on, just like many of us do & works on this game in his free time, which all things considered, seems like he must generally make a point to set most of it aside, to attend to this game.  Also, he does personally respond to posts, just not every single one & not all day, every day.  I personally can relate to that, as Ive got a super busy schedule myself, sometimes too busy & have to prioritize the stuff I want to do VS the stuff I need to do, & even stopping all that to do something simple, like respond to a text or email, can add more to my plate then I can already handle at that time.  I think a lot of Devs here on Steam fit into that category, as most of them arent full time programmers/game-designers & their game isnt their main source of income.  Some Devs dont bother to read &/or respond to their customers ever, but this Dev does fairly often.  And to me, as long as that level of customer service/interaction continues & the game keeps moving forward in a positive direction as its been; thats all that matters to me & all I care about, to warrant supporting this or any Dev, that demonstrates that on-going level of commitment.Bugs:The last time Id put any time into this game was appx 2-3 months ago ( from time of this review @ Dec 17th 2016 ) & had been wanting to play the game again after the last few updates/bug fixes & try out the new DLC.So recently I was able to play several hours off & on over the last week.  Started a new game, after buying the new DLC.  Everything was running smooth & working great at first, with a few minor bugs like; every time saving & quitting then reloading save game, the same few tutorial help boxes popped up, like if youre starting a new game.  Or while paused, clicking expand land, you hear the SFX of game like it was running even though visually, the game still appeared paused.  Nothing big or game breaking at all.Some more problematic things started to occur later on tho, like upon saving & reloading, most NPCs were unhappy & leaving, with no indication there was a prob prior to saving & quitting.  To be fair, Dev has a thread stating if you have probs be sure to erase that data which Im not sure I did this last replay. http://steamcommunity.com/app/314240/discussions/0/35221584437504412/Despite any bugs or probs along the way, I have faith in this Dev, from his past actions, not just words & promises like some Devs can do.  My honest opinion is, if you like what you see advertised here from the games Vids & Description, then you cant go wrong buying this game.  Its pretty much exactly/mostly what youd want & expect from a game like this.  Its not however a super duper in-depth game.  And its not meant to be & doesnt have to be to still be fun & enjoyable.  Nor is it on the shallow end either.  Overall its more of a mid-depth semi-casual gaming experience with several aspects that are still nicely in-depth, with other aspects to still keep you on your toes & wanting to continue to play, manage, grow & expand your kingdom.Bottom line is, this games been in development for a while now & continues to progress steadily, considering its from an Inde Dev.  Depending on the current state of the game & where its at, you may experience a relatively bug-free game, or you may be in the middle of a recent content update with the inevitable bugs that follow, which TBH, yes can get frustrating.  But thinking about it... Why does one get frustrated with something in the first place, instead of just not even caring or thinking twice about it & instead just walk away?  Cuz you care about it.  Cuz you like it.  Cuz theres some part of you that has a vested interest in that thing to begin with lol.  Which is ultimately a testament & compliment to RPG Tycoon & what it does right & why its worth most peoples time even now, & especially once its 100% finished.  And which is why Im still glad I bought this game, even tho it has some polishing to do yet & hopefully a few more features/game-play additions.  I look forward to the future when well see this game in its fully realized, finished state.  ( :

Early Access Review
								I got this game gifted to me and decided to try it (I also had the option of using it in a group giveaway) because the concept looked interesting to me. At first, I wanted to wait until more time had passed before doing this review, but I really don't see much potential here.If you like RPG-based management of mercenary heroes and your own village, you might like this game. More likely, however, you won't.The aesthetics are okay - very simple, blocky graphics that remind me of games you could easily find on gaming websites like Kongregate and Newgrounds. The music is decent, but can and will get annoying fairly quickly. The controls are easy - lots of clicking on menus extremely remniscent of Game Dev Tycoon (GDT). Many reviews for this game point Game Dev Tycoon as a source of inspiration for this game, however, you could honestly think of this as a much weaker, boring attempt to pay homage to GDT. There isn't really a tutorial function, but everything is pretty straightforward. For some strange reason, dirt roads are very expensive to make (not cost-efficient at all), so DO NOT make any. They don't really seem to do anything either. The learning curve is minimal, but wonky. There are combinations you can do when sending your heroes on missions - for example, certain villages prefer certain missions, and every mission requires you to select "attributes" to put your skill points into (ala GDT). Mission example: when you send your hero on a supply run for village x, you can decide to put a few points in horses (seems to speed up mission completion time), weapons, food, and conduct (seems to do absolutely nothing). Or, you can choose to allocate points to bravado, to scouting, stealth, and aggression. Depending on how "compatible" your mission, selected village, and allocated points are, you will accumulate points in "loot," "influence," and "damage" (again, ala GDT).The higher your loot value, the more llikely you are to receive items (ex: weapons, shields). You can sell these all at once or equip them to your heroes (they can only equip one item at a time) for stat boosts. Influence and damage values affect how many followers you will receive/lose after mission completion. I think followers add to your money-generated-over-time, which comes from things like potions being sold at an alchemy store. You also gain renown after completing missions, which is used in combination with gold to purchase building upgrades like more buildings (many features are incomplete or locked at the moment).During missions, you will be presented with 3 scenarios (they are always the same) where you must select a "strategy" for your hero to use (ex: be confrontational, talk your way through, or work around it. Again, depending on what you choose and its compatibility with your selected mission, you will gain points in the 3 main mission counters (loot, influence, damage). This game is clearly in early, early access, and I strongly recommend you do not get this (or at least wait until it's released as a finished product). You cannot sell items once you decide to keep them (the sell option is grayed out, so you have to pick "sell" right when you complete a mission and are shownn the loot screen if you want extra gold). You can find new villages and missions with the "explore" option, but it just unlocks more boring, tedious artificial-game-lengtheners. Honestly, if you want to play a game like this, I STRONGLY suggest you turn away and pick up Game Dev Tycoon instead.That game at least has a lot of variety and aesthetics for you to enjoy.At least for now, wait to see how this develops (if you are really, really interested). Even if you are dying to try this, I implore you to wait until it is out of early access.Do not recommend.Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

Also another petpeeve i've developed is with the arbitrary award system at the end of the year. In dungeon village the village and its heros in particular are awarded medals which are actual items that can be used to improve a hero's stats across the board. I'm not suggesting that exact thing but I would prefer something other than numbers and letters at the end of the year as this just does not add anything special to the game for me in particular. Lastly, and remember I have not played through the entire game since the last update but I feel as though the random events could be more than just global modifiers maybe something more interactive or under your control or the option to attempt to control the event would be preferable than just accepting the event as is. I suggest maybe also adding something similar to the dice roll system from epic quests allowing your heros to not only quest for settlements but to have the chance to maybe protect, improve, prevent, etc options for a global modifier event. If they fail the event is worse, if they succeed they improve the modifier, if they do nothing it remains the same as it currently is. Anyway I will be returning to play this after work, and the game as it has now become and currently is, worthy of purchase and worthy of your playtime. I don't know the developer or what he is working with but I saw a pile of crap spread on an empty canvas become a beautiful painting that still needs a slight touch up. Good work man and please continue to do your best and follow your own vision more so than the people who make suggestions because in the end they bought your game because of your decisions and visions and alot of developers seem to bow down to every crappy suggestion that sounds good on paper but damages the core gameplay that originally attracted that same person who made the suggestion to the game in the first place. tl;dr keep doing your own thing, but stay open minded to suggestions that may still be useful or an improvement to your vision.Edit: Forgot to mention, I love the settlement of Threepwood, I can't put my finger on why but it seems familiar and friendly to me.

												This comes down to early access as a concept. The idea is to support very small indie developers with a great concept that you would like to see developed. There are countless articles in the gaming press about how studios are taking less and less chances since games cost so much to make. This means fewer new IPs or game series and the first genres to suffer are the niches like management/tycoon/sim. This is because it's a smaller audience and a group that by nature waits for sales and opportunities to buy games(trained to look for a bargain by the very games that suffer due to this emotional IQ) for less. If you want games like this your only chance is to continue to support titles like this one in Early Access. To be honest, half will turn out as garbage. A 1/4 will be an outright waste. Another 1/4 though will turn out to be a gem that guides the genre for the next few years and that's worth taking chances. For a genre that simulates business you need to follow the real guideline which is perseverence in the face of staggering odds. 9/10 new businesses fail(false but often quoted stat) and that should roughly guide you when buying EA titles in this genre. You don't avoid starting a business because your chances are small. In fact the reason you keep going is because that eventual success is worth it. Is this game great...no. However, it has good ideas and flawed execution. Common to EA and this genre. You should buy it to experience it's better mechanics and ideas. You should buy it to show the developers that there is still a market for this type of game. You should buy it to keep this developer making games. His next will be better than this. Eventually he could make the gold standard tycoon game. If you don't support it because it's not perfect then you guarantee the chances of playing a great management game go down for all of us. That's the simple fact.

Final ThoughtsNot recommended.Game crashed before the tutorial was able to be completed. Occasional user interface (UI) elements persisted on the screen after a menu was closed, the only way to clear the screen was to quit the game and reload. Questing is tedious with a lack of polish to the interface. The hero management interface is broken and only half the intended features seem to work. The item systems is just barely working at this point resulting in game breaking bugs and lost inventory.IntroductionThis game is a unique twist on the classical RPG formula where instead of playing the hero, you manage their city. There are no monsters to battle, but you can train your heroes to improve their base statistics, solve quests to gain followers and cash. The ability to send multiple heroes in a party on epic quests is also fun. Sometimes a sub-quest involving the vanquishing of a villain appears or substantially better loot is to be had. The town has special buildings available once a certain level of experience is obtained.QuestingSending your heroes out on a quest involves a somewhat unique screen where you have to select six pieces of equipment they will take on their journey. This is interesting at first since each piece of equipment has a priority and some does nothing to assist the quest. As the heroes quest, more equipment and missions are unlocked. Once the equipment is placed in its correct priority slot, the mission results in better rewards. Unfortunately, the next time a hero goes on the same quest, this entire setup must be repeated. It gets tedious after a while since ultimately there are 30 different pieces of equipment available and the selection screen is limited to what it displays so there is a lot of scrolling involved. Understandably, the developers added a history screen and indicators to what equipment may be useful, though frustratingly they have this on a different "history" screen which causes a lot of back and fourth between the two windows.HeroesThe hero hire screen allows a hero to be hired. The statistics attached to each one has no explanation to what they are for resulting in either a lookup on the internet or just selecting randomly. Once a hero has been hired, they wander the town doing nothing unless they are actively on a quest. Once back from a quest they will be tired or injured. They must be selected on the main map screen and directed to the healing facilities. The hero management interface is broken and telling a hero to go heal from that screen results in the hero ignore the command. This is especially frustrating if there are many civilians exploring the town since it is hard to find a particular hero in the crowd. However, the training options from the hero management work, so get them guns son.ItemsThere seems to be a nice collection of fun items to acquire over the course of a game. Some improve the city, some are equitable on heroes. Unfortunately some of the biggest game breaking bugs come from items. Certain city improvements (rugs and pots) can be used to improve vendors in the game. After making an improvement, the item doesn't disappear and can be reused multiple times. After nearly five minutes upgrading all the vendors millions of gold were added to the treasury every time anything was purchased. Once the upgrades to the city were finished, any items left in the inventory were missing.

												Let me start off with this, this game is really nice. I've been playing nonstop for the past few hours now and it's a really smooth playing game. There is a little learning curve(bankrupted my first kingdom) but once you get used to it, it's not hard. I'll start with my first impressions. There is a tutorial that I'm guessing helps you through it(I skipped it and learned by mistake). The game starts off kinda tedious because you only have a few quick quests you can do at the start and you just cycle through all 5 until you get a few more. You luckily don't have to remember what works best for each quest because it has a history feature which shows what goes with what. The art style reminds me of tycoon type games back in the 90s and early 2000s. The UI is nice and easy to understand with tooltips telling you what each button does. I noticed a few typos but nothing a hotfix can't remedy. After a few hours the game starts to pick up because you can now start what are called Epic Quests. Epic Quests are quests that take 2 or more heroes to start. These quests allow you to get more supplies and quick quests as well as other valuable items like weapons and armor. You don't need to do epic quests just to get more quick quests once you unlock the library(I think kingdom level 3) you can research all types of things from lower maintenance costs for your buildings to more followers per settlement. Don't get me started on modding this game. It's one of the easiest games to mod. First off everything is shown in pretty much plain text(XML) and they have a whole page of the site to help with modding the game. Let's say you want to mod the UI to have a few different textures(I completely changed the color of the UI to green, which you can get on the workshop) all you have to do is go into the UI.png spritesheet change the text you want and next time you load the game it's changed. I recommend making the mod in a folder in the mods folder to make disabling and enabling them easier. Adding quests and heroes is also very easy by just adding a new line to the heroes.xml. Pros:- Easy to use interface- Modding support- Self-explanatory UI and functions- 90s and early 2000s tycoon nostalgia look and feelCons:- Few bugs- Little grindyRating:9.5/10Edit: The customer support is amazing. The new update(1.0.6) broke my save but the dev is already pushing out a fix for it and it's only been like an hour. Not only that but he also helped me through any help I needed for modding.

												I've enjoyed this game so far, though honestly a majority of the enjoyment has come from unlocking achievements rather than the content of the game itself since it's fairly simplistic once you realize how to make money on the base game.  Most games of the tycoon or city builder nature have multiple resources competing and impacting your progress, with selection of stats to grow being very impactful to your success.In RPG Tycoon, the only really significant resource is money and everything else is tiertiary at best unless your aiming at unlocking specific achievements (which is what I've enjoyed doing!).  A single resource isn't necessarily a bad thing, however there's also only really one effective way to get that resource, and that is quests.  Within a single game, you'll come across the same quests multiple times, and while it's nice the first playthrough to see what the alternative choices would get you, it gets a bit grindy.As your heroes grow, so does the amount of gold quests give.  This also keeps your settlements happy, so you don't need to choose between doing quests and having your heroes help around town since the answer is always do quests.  This results in the game getting a bit on the grindy side, but since I'm usually playing it while doing something else such as cooking or waiting for something to compile, it doesn't bother me as much as if I were trying to sit down and stay focused only on the game.That said, I liked the game though it's very simplistic (nothing really matters but money, even though the "Grow Your Kingdom" tasks make you feel like you might have something to do other than run quests over and over again to grind out more money.  The only decisions you really make early on are avoiding going into severe debt early on because you don't know to grind quick quests and epics for cash yet.The idea behind this game is great, but the execution still needs a bit more work and polish.I'm hopeful the game will continue to improve with updates since it's been updated rather frequently recently, so I am currently recommending it!EDIT: I also agreed with the reviews about a number of bugs that break the game, but that said when I came across an issue, it was fixed within the next update after I posted a review about it, so I can't really complain too much there.As a result, I'll be buying the expansion & update my review later.

Its graphics seem quite nice and are 3D skyview graphics which more games definitely need. 								Brief summary of beta version of RPG Tycoon- Game is very buggy as warned, looks very promising but needs to take some pages from successful GameDev Tycoon. Elongated breakdown-Opened up my Store on steam to see this little Number pop up! Well hello little number maybe a 1 or even a lil .5. Nonetheless this game was there and as I really have enjoyed playing GameDevTycoon. I think this game can really learn a few things from Gamedev...Graphics- The graphics are good and very reminiscent of old school Runescape. Which plays in very well into the game.Sliders- The sliders don't make much sense and is very vague.. Also are very cumbersome and need some better sound effects the default Window sound is very unappealing.Knowledge in Game- When you begin the game you are very overwhelmed and yet underwhelmed. You get some basic knowledge and are confused at the same time. You have no idea about what is working within the quests (like within the sliders and what works with what also point allocation). Point allocation- The game has a bug where you can adjust the top portion of the allocation system by minusing them and have it return next quest with the points still remaining where you added them last time. Money- I had no idea you lost the game when you ran out of money and so I ended the game within 2 mins by trying to build my city in more and adding roads.. To only have the game be all like you suck GG.Visitors-Their bubbles of text get stuck behind buildings and cannot be read.Quests and making money- NOOO Clue how to make good money, felt like I’m just waiting for my quests tooooo sllllooowwwwllllyyyy produce the little change each time.. Perhaps needs to be upped a bit? or I'm just a bit inpatient, who knows probably the second. The quests also need to be clearer and more feedback is needed and perhaps a memory system again similar to GameDev...UI- is very clear and clean but needs some better animations and sound effects. Hopefully they will add in better tutorials and make the game easier to jump in. Questing- Please make the UI more fun and clear when your hero is on a quest. You get no idea why points are getting added into the certain places. As I said before game looks great, shows a lot of promise and I can't wait for it to be finished to really log in some hours. I hope they change the music to something a lil catchier, add in some better sound effects, update the UI a bit more, and clean up the game all around to be honest. Early Access Review
								**********Updated 2/10/2015**********Below you'll see my previous reviews, I'm keeping them there as the review grows, so that any who are interested can see the progress made.Just like last time, I'll list off bugs first:1: Whenever two heroes rest in the same building, one of them will get locked in that building, and will never come out. the only way to get that hero back, is to sack them, watch their avatar leave the town and then rehire them.2: Various mispellings, if those even count as bugs.3: That's it, I haven't encountered any other bugs lately.Btw, for a TL;DR version, scroll to the bottom, just before the next updated line.So how is the game different now?Quick Quests now have a unique gameplay to them, that I haven't played in another tycoon game.First you select a town, then you select a quest type, after selecting that quest type, you have a screen of supplies, the supply screen is what I can assume the influences from Game Dev Tycoon turned into, and it adapts well.You see, each town requires different supplies on different quests, so even if you do a Raider quest in town A, and get all 6 supplies matched in their correct slots, that doesn't mean it'll be the same way in town B.You also do not get all the supplies straight off the bat, while I can't say I like having those supplies withheld, it makes for a lot of replayability as you try and earn all the supplies, so it ends up being pretty damn enjoyable.The Epic quests however feel lacking in comparison to the quick quests, and I think they could really utilise their own unique gameplay, I already see evidence of how this could be achieved with the mid quest story prompts, but I'd like to see something at the start, similar to quick quest's preparation stage, but unique.I don't understand the bounties very well at the moment, I searched for a villain and afterward that quest line became unaccessible.One of my major complaints in the previous versions was the lack of feedback, this has been corrected and there's now a lot of information on the screen, The hud can feel a bit encumbering, I'd like to either see the hud size be controllable in the options, but that wouldn't need to be an exact option, many other solutions would work.The top left window can be minimized but others can not. however, the bottom left one, shouldn't be able to be minimized, I'd rather see it fade into the background when a target isn't selected. I'd also like to see the bottom left window only function when a target is clicked instead of hovered over.The top right information feed, feels rather rough, the messages don't need to stay for long and could actually be automatically deleted for you, I'm sure though that the developer is looking at this, with his own solution in mind.The rest of the hud however, is well designed, pleasing to the eyes and gives relevant information.The research is good, but feels like it lacks a lot of research, and I'd like to see it play a second role.The town management is coming along nicely, and while playing, I actually thought that it was possible to create a self sustaining town, that does not rely on the funds from your heroes.I would like to see that be a thing, a self sustaining town, but I'd rather see it as a possible avenue for development in the game that you have to specifically pursue, and not an eventuality that every playthrough will lead to.TL;DR:The game is now at a playable stage, and the game finally has a strong foundation to fall back on, that doesn't take too heavily from other games.It's enjoyable, and in the playthrough that lead to this updated review, I actually sunk a few hours into it all at once.Rating:What it is: 6.5/10What it could be: 9/10I'm excited to see the end product when it leaves early access, I believe it'd net a 7.5/10 at this rate.********Updated 18/03/2015********First off, a lot of my old points are still rather relevant, the game hasn't terribly improved, and still stands as one of the more broken Early Access games I've played.First to the bugs:I haven't encountered any of the old bugs, but now I've met some of the new ones, one of them is map scrolling, if you roll your cursor to the edge, it scrolls, simple, lots of games have that, but some times when you roll your cursor to one of the edges, it doesn't scroll the map, and you have to jiggle the cursor at the right side of the screen to free it up.Then there's the auto continue, whenever a message pops up, something in the game will happen for example: auto save and the game will continue without me, while I read, the messages are quite length in this game too, so that creates a problem.Finally autosaving also flashes the screen, which is insanely annoying.The developer has steered away from it's Game Dev Tycoon inspired system, however it's current system isn't very interesting, and is still rather cryptic, because you don't get enough feedback after a quest as to why you got a bad rating, and some times the messages get repeated meaning what could have been a useful third message gets pushed off the table by a message I've already read.The game still isn't very interesting, and often puts me asleep, Still not a fan of the art direction, and the gameplay is lacking.At this time, I do not recommend this game.4/10 for the game as is.8/10 for the potential game, that I hope it one day becomes.******First Version******First off, I have to quickly explain:No, I do not hate this game, I actually really really like it and it's concept.The recommendation is in reference to it's playability in the current build.With that out of the way.RPG Tycoon scratches an itch that I love, Management games, I've had a thing for them since I played Rollercoaster Tycoon 2.So the ability to create my own RPG town, send heroes on quests and promote my town sounds like a heavenly game to me.But RPG Tycoon is still in early access, the major reason I do not recommend it is bugs, the game is at this current stage full of bugs and glitches, which is not surprising with an Early Access game, that's just early access for you, the developers are still making the game, bugs and glitches are to be expected, But at this time due to some game breaking bugs I can't recommend it.These bugs include (but are only limited to what I've seen thus far)-Duplicating heroes-Time pausing days not progressing but quests remaining open and progressing without reaching a climax.-Saving and Loading does not take the game back to before the bugs occured (not a bug, but is annoying when trying to avoid bugs)And with that part out of the way, here is the rest of my thoughts:The concept is great, I can't wait to see this in a playable state.The graphic style itself I can't say I'm a fan of, I'd like it to be different, but at the same time, it doesn't matter, I'll happily ignore that.The Game Dev Tycoon type of direction with quests is both familiar and inviting, making me wish to try the same quest multiple times, however I feel there needs to be a way to investigate these quests to get hints at what are the right and wrong choices.The music is excellent, it reminds me of minecraft but not in a way that feels bland and unoriginal, the music feels like a winner.Add in random events to the final release? that would be amazing.I can't wait to see the potential for large towns with sprawlling citizens and several different buildings like blacksmith, tailor and what not.I'd like to also request a micromanagement system with the citizens, giving them jobs I mean, and having them live within your city.I have so many high hopes for this game, and I can't wait until it's in a more playable state so I can sit down for a good while and play it.Buy it? please do! the more purchases the more funding, the more funding the quick and better the progression.

								Like many other reviews I give this thumbs up for potential.  The game still needs a ton of work and fine tuning and, frankly, content.On the PROS side is the basic concept.  Run a village as AI Heroes do all the adventuring.  I have no doubt the finished product will be a good game and worth the money, but I'm holding out hope that it will be a great game that is a steal for the price.On the CONS side there is a quite a bit wrong or off.  The FTL lite "Epic Quests" feel like random 50/50 guesses.  When it asked me to help a farmer with his pigs 4 times in 4 straight quests I said "yes" all four times.  Wrong each time.  However I have no idea how this matters other than XP not gained.  This transitions nicely into the overall lack of a feeling that my decisions matter other than keeping the town in net gains money wise.  2 hours into the game and I don't even read the quest bits anymore, I just pick and option at random and roll on.  100+ hours in FTL and I still read the text.The notifications are also super annoying, they constantly pop up to tell me that it is autosaving, which by the way is frequent and necessary, and to tell me a quest is done.  Of course the quest is done, I just navigated a bunch of pop ups telling me the same information.  Again, we are dealing with information that quickly becomes superflous, which is not a great trait for a resource management game to have.The bonus giving objective queue seems to run out after about 4 sets, though if I remember correctly the Dev noted that is going to be a big part of the next update.I know I mostly have complaints/critiques here, and I could probably find more.  So why recommended still? Because I really really want this game to be great, it's my first alpha build purchase and I want other people to try it out and offer even smarter feedback than I can.Thanks for what you are doing Dev, for the large amount of resource management games out there the lack of quality and non-Farmville variety is sad.  Keep working hard and making this game everything it can grow to be!
